abstracts.cdata!:
The Sustainable Coastal Tourism Project
            will develop an efficient management for tourism
            sustainability along the northern coast of Honduras,
            including the Bay Islands, and improve the socioeconomic
            conditions of local communities. This environmental
            assessment (EA) highlights the need to strengthen the
            institutional capacity of the Honduras Institute of
            Tourism's (HIT) Environmental Unit, in order to enforce
            an effective legal environmental framework, particularly
            regarding environmental health, water quality, effluent
            contamination, and cultural heritage preservation. Measures
            to mitigate adverse environmental impacts call for: 1)
            establishment of an environmental management system to
            define control regulations, and procedures. Consulting
            services will provide expertise in strategic environmental
            planning, and legislation, and foster administrative
            changes; 2) implementation of a simplified geographical
            information system, through pilot studies focused on
            municipal environmental inventory, identifying sources of
            contamination, and degradation to provide effective
            technical norms; 3) implementation of a diffusion training
            program, and strengthening of the Environmental Management
            Unit of HIT, to incorporate a multi-disciplinary team,
            responsive to legal, auditing, and environmental control;
            and, 4) establishment of environmental monitoring, and
            evaluation techniques.
